content.webTitle: Guardian columnist Suzanne Moore wins Orwell prize for journalism

fields.headline: Guardian columnist Suzanne Moore wins Orwell prize for journalism
fields.bodyText: Guardian columnist Suzanne Moore has been awarded the prestigious Orwell prize for journalism jointly with the deputy editor of Prospect magazine, Steve Bloomfield. Suzanne was commended for her articles on attitudes to Bill Clinton and Monica Lewinsky in the wake of the #MeToo movement; why she was wrong to refuse to wear a poppy for remembrance; and why she did not take part in the march for a People’s Vote. Run by the Orwell Foundation, the Orwell prize is awarded to the best commentary or reporting which comes closest to achieving writer George Orwell’s ambition to “make political writing into an art.” Judges commented: “The journalism that has won these two prizes represents the best of the Orwell tradition, incisive, relevant and human. It also represents the two sides of his journalism: there is Suzanne Moore’s stubborn and brave commentary, and Steve Bloomfield’s forensic research and reporting.” More details about the awards can be found here.
